title: Locations & Going Places
objectives: Learn vocabulary for common places and locations
Use 있다/없다 to express existence and location
context: Being able to talk about places and navigate is essential, whether you're traveling in Korea, meeting friends, or just talking about your day. Korean uses specific particles to mark locations, which makes expressing 'at', 'to', 'from', and 'in' very precise.

Did you know? Korean has different location particles depending on whether you're talking about movement (going TO a place) or static location (being AT a place). This distinction is built into the grammar through particles, making Korean very specific about spatial relationships!

This lesson will teach you common places you'll encounter in daily life - from home and school to restaurants and subway stations. You'll also learn how to ask 'where?' and give simple directions using location particles.
You'll master 있어요/없어요 (to exist/not exist), which is used for both 'I have' and 'there is'. This versatile verb is one of the most important in Korean!

vocabulary.english: to exist, to have, to be (somewhere)
to not exist, to not have

sentences.english: I'm at home / It's at home
There's a park in front of the school
The hospital is next to the market

explanation: Location Particle 에: Used for destination (to) and static location (at). Examples: 학교에 가요 (go TO school), 집에 있어요 (at home). Use 에 with location verbs like 가다, 오다, 있다.
Action Location 에서: Used when an ACTION happens AT a location. Examples: 식당에서 먹어요 (eat AT restaurant), 공원에서 일해요 (work AT park). Don't confuse with 에!
에 vs 에서: Key difference - 에 = destination/static location, 에서 = action location. 'I'm at home' = 집에 있어요 (에). 'I work at home' = 집에서 일해요 (에서). Both use 'at' in English!
있다 (to exist/have): Very versatile verb! Meanings: 1) To exist/be located: 여기 있어요 (it's here), 2) To have: 친구가 있어요 (I have friends), 3) To be present: 집에 있어요 (I'm at home).
없다 (to not exist): Opposite of 있다. Examples: 시간이 없어요 (I don't have time), 여기 없어요 (it's not here). Conjugates to 없어요, not 없아요!
Positional Nouns: 앞 (front), 뒤 (back), 옆 (side), 위 (above), 아래 (below), 안 (inside), 밖 (outside). Add 에 for 'at/in': 앞에 (in front), 옆에 (next to), 안에 (inside).
여기/거기/저기: 여기 (here, near me), 거기 (there, near you), 저기 (over there, far from both). Similar to this/that/that over there. Add 에 for 'at': 여기에, 거기에, 저기에.
Asking Where: 어디 (where) + 예요 = 어디예요? (where is it?). For more formal: 어디에 있어요? (where is it located?). Example: 화장실이 어디예요? (Where is the bathroom?)
